title: VisiCalc
overview: The first spreadsheet software, VisiCalc, launches on the Apple II, revolutionizing business computing and personal productivity.

title: Lotus 1-2-3
overview: Lotus 1-2-3 dominates the business software market in the 1980s, combining spreadsheet, database, and charting functions.

title: Microsoft Excel
overview: Microsoft launches Excel, eventually surpassing Lotus 1-2-3 as the dominant spreadsheet tool for businesses worldwide.

title: Microsoft Office
overview: Microsoft Office bundles Word, Excel, and PowerPoint into a suite, becoming the standard for office productivity software.

title: Adobe Photoshop
overview: Adobe releases Photoshop, which quickly becomes the industry standard for digital image editing and creative design.

title: Apache HTTP Server
overview: The Apache HTTP Server launches, becoming the most widely used open-source web server and a backbone of the early Internet.

title: Winamp
overview: Winamp is released, becoming the most popular MP3 player of the late 1990s and fueling the digital music revolution.

title: Google Search
overview: Google launches its search engine, redefining how people access and navigate the Internet, later becoming a tech giant.

title: Wikipedia
overview: Wikipedia goes live, establishing the worldâ€™s largest free encyclopedia, written collaboratively by volunteers worldwide.

title: Skype
overview: Skype introduces free VoIP calls over the Internet, disrupting the telecom industry and popularizing global online communication.

title: Dropbox
overview: Dropbox launches, pioneering consumer-friendly cloud file storage and synchronization across devices.

title: Spotify
overview: Spotify launches in Europe, introducing a streaming music service that transforms how people consume and pay for music.

title: Zoom
overview: Zoom launches as a video conferencing tool, later becoming one of the most critical platforms during the COVID-19 pandemic.
